awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Social Diffusion in Online Media for Reaching Hidden Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to use peer-driven recruitment to sample from and send information to hidden, underrepresented, or underground online communities. Specifically, the project will examine how social media can be used to extract information from and distribute information to hidden communities, determine whether the framework to be developed can provide new insights into the behavior of community members, advance the science of peer-to-peer sampling techniques, and determine whether trust in social media affects the peer-to-peer recruitment process. 

Intellectual Merit 
This project will serve to answer the following questions. How can we best apply computational resources that are associated with online social media to improve processes for collecting information from and distributing information to hidden populations? To what degree do the known deficiencies in state-of-the-art bias estimators impact the effectiveness of peer-to-peer-based sampling and how well can these deficiencies be corrected by new estimators and/or sampling design? To what extent do individuals invest trust in various social media (particularly Facebook and email) and how much does degree-of-trust affect peer-to-peer recruitment processes, especially with respect to identification with a hidden or marginalized group? These are important questions, and answers to them will serve to advance the both the social and computational sciences, and their synergistic combinations. 

Broader Impacts 
This project will provide an open source system for remotely interacting with online communities, particularly but not limited to hidden communities. The project will have a substantial education component in that the proposed system will have a simulation mode that will enable it to be used for class projects. By providing a way to address problems that impact underrepresented groups, it will also provide meaningful research and educational opportunities in computing to members of those groups. In addition, it will establish an interdisciplinary, intercollegiate laboratory in online social network research that will institutionalize preexisting working relationships and provide a home for an ongoing seminar series in network science.

por.por_cntn:
The Intellectual merit of our project was to investigate the dynamics of how ideas are communicated across social networks, and how this could be leveraged to reach 'hidden' or otherwise difficult to reach individuals within the network. A variety of computational and network analytical approaches were used to identify key factors that influence the ability to reach 'hidden' individuals or groups within a network. Our findings have significant implications for health data science especially considering how analogous applications of our approach were generalizable to other problems, such as infectious diseases, food poisoning, and mental health concerns.

These broader impacts of our project allowed our collaborative group to place a major emphasis on education and outreach. We developed a research opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral learners that integrated our research findings into hands-on learning activities. Additionally, we presented our findings to the scientific community, as well as to policymakers and community members to share our results and engage in discussions about the potential uses of our work in disease prevention and health promotion.

Overall, our project has made important contributions to both the scientific community and society as a whole. Through our research and outreach efforts, we have advanced our understanding of how social networks and similar kinds of network structures can be leveraged to both "pull" in information from hidden or difficult to reach individuals or groups, as well as to "push" information or targeted interventions to these same difficult-to-reach targets with high precision. Further, we provided educational opportunities for future generations of scientists and policymakers.
